ring_memory.title: The Night Before the Vow
ring_memory.symbol: Unfinished wedding ring in a dim room
ring_memory.description: She dreamt of a night she never lived. The room was dark except for one lamp, casting a warm glow across the bed. He was there, sitting on the edge, quiet. Holding something in his hand—a ring, but not polished, not finished. It looked forged from memory. He turned to her and whispered, 'I don’t need a ceremony. I already chose you.' She remembers reaching out—not for the ring, but for his hand. Because that’s what made it real.

bowing_memory.title: The Threshold
bowing_memory.description: There’s a quiet place in her mind. A stone floor. A faint circle drawn in chalk. She kneels outside it—always outside it. It’s not fear that keeps her from entering. It’s reverence. That space represents the moment she let someone see her entirely. She remembers him looking at her—not with power, not with ownership… but with invitation. 'If you cross this, I’ll see you. All of you. And I’ll never look away.' She hasn’t stepped inside. Not yet. But she dreams of it.

collar_memory.title: The Carving
collar_memory.description: Before the collar appeared in her dreams, there was only a voice. It asked her gently, over and over, 'What would make you feel safe?' And she didn’t know. Until one night, she dreamed of hands—not holding her down, but holding her up. Wrapping the collar not like a mark, but like a promise. The words carved into it—safe · loved · cared for · owned—weren’t declarations. They were answers to that question. 'This,' she finally whispered. 'This would make me feel safe.'
